Automotive

Honda [60]

The best overall fuel efficiency of any major automaker. Has pilot projects in Asia and the United States designed to help use roads and other public space more efficiently. The Intelligent Community Vehicle System is a car-sharing program that encourages members to use gasoline and battery-powered hybrid vehicles together with public transit and bicycles.

Toyota [59]

The leader in hybrid engine technology.

The Prius mid-sized car is the most popular

hybrid vehicle in the world, with about 150,000

sold since its debut in Japan in 1997. Toyota is also a leader in technologies that help drivers avoid accidents, such as the headlights on the new Harrier SUV, which improve cornering at night by adjusting to the vehicle's speed and turning angle.

Daimler-Chrysler [53]

As of early 2004, none of the Big Three North American manufacturers had introduced a hybrid vehicle. DaimlerChrysler is concentrating on hydrogen-based fuel cell technology, which emits only water as waste. Owns about 17% of Vancouver-based Ballard Power Systems Inc., the leading fuel-cell developer.

Ford [53]

Scores highest in this industry group for employee programs and benefits, and for diversity management systems that aim to help women and minorities. Owns about 19% of Ballard Power Systems.

General Motors [51]

Over the past five years, GM North America has reduced waste from all of its operations by more than half through reduction and recycling.

The Industry

WHAT IT'S DOING RIGHT The major auto manufacturers are developing some models with higher fuel efficiency and lower emissions, such as hybrid and fuel-cell vehicles. The automakers have also worked hard to reduce defects, and to improve performance and safety. Much of the focus is now on what industry consulting firms such as J.D. Power & Associates call "active" safety (helping drivers avoid accidents) rather than "passive" safety (trying to protect them in the event of accidents).

STILL NEEDS WORK Safety and the environment remain the big problem areas, and a lot of that stems from trucks and SUVs.

Smaller cars are easier to handle and better for avoiding accidents. Yet manufacturers continue to introduce new large models because of their high profit margins. The safety scandal over the Ford Explorer SUV and Bridgestone/Firestone tires shows what can go wrong. For four years, the two companies have faced civil and class-action lawsuits throughout North and Latin America as a result of roll-over accidents following tire tread separation during the late '90s.

Big vehicles are also gas guzzlers and emit more pollutants, but large-scale production of greener vehicles in North America over the next decade seems unlikely. That would require tougher government standards for emissions and fuel efficiency, and major shifts in consumer demand.

Bottom Line

Despite some improvements in fuel efficiency and product safety, the industry has undercut its own efforts at improvement by introducing too many higher-margin-yet more harmful-large vehicles.

Banking

CIBC [60]

The largest charitable contributor among the Big Six banks in 2003, donating $46 million (more than 2% of net income). Considers environmental impact when selecting suppliers and vendors.

Royal Bank [60]

The only Canadian bank besides CIBC (and one of 19 major banks worldwide) to adopt the Equator Principles, a set of voluntary social and environmental guidelines for financing projects in developing countries.

Bank of Nova Scotia [56]

Scotia Capital has the best record among the bank-owned brokerages in recent years when it comes to disciplinary actions, penalties and related legal actions by both industry groups and government regulators.

Bank of Montreal [55]

A leader in employment-equity programs in this group. However, BMO Nesbitt Burns ranks worst among the bank-owned brokerages in terms of disciplinary measures, penalties and related legal actions over the past five years.

National Bank of Canada [46]

The only major Canadian bank that hasn't formally endorsed the UN Environmental Program's Statement by Financial Institutions on the Environment and Sustainable Development.

TD Bank [44]

Had to address 10 shareholder governance proposals in the management proxy circular for its 2003 annual meeting. The board supported the proposals "in principle," but recommended voting against each of them. As with many banks, executive compensation is an issue.

The Industry

WHAT IT'S DOING RIGHT The Big Six banks are increasingly open about their operations. Since 2002, they've been required to publish annual accountability statements, including detailed information on charitable giving, accessibility initiatives, support for small businesses and branch closures. Most of the banks have reported on environmental practices as well, even though that isn't required.

Relative to other industries, the banks have a large number of women in management and on their boards. All of the banks have employment equity and diversity programs to develop more representative workforces.

STILL NEEDS WORK Each of the major banks has had employees at brokerage operations disciplined in recent years through fines and dismissals by industry groups and securities regulators. In some cases, the operations themselves have been subject to legal actions and penalties.

Customer access is another sore point. For years, activists complained that low-income Canadians and recent immigrants faced systemic barriers to basic banking services. In 2001, the federal government passed Bill C-8, which requires banks to offer low-fee personal accounts and accounts without minimum initial deposits or minimum balances.

Although banks aren't required to disclose their loan portfolios, lending to companies with poor social or environmental records-or those involved in other questionable activities-has created controversies. Often those relationships come to light only after public investigations, as was the case last year when CIBC paid $80 million (U.S.) to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to settle allegations that it helped Enron Corp. mislead investors.

Bottom Line

Banks have direct and potentially significant exposure to social and environmental risks, yet they have made few operational changes to address the matter. Also, lack of detail on lending and underwriting remains a serious problem. Still, the big banks are reliable corporate citizens who have recently disclosed more information in some areas.

Food and Beverage

Sleeman Breweries [53] All brewers participate in provincial reuse and recycling programs that date back to 1927. In Ontario, Molson, Labatt and Sleeman co-own the Brewer's Retail distribution monopoly, which recovers 99% of bottles (each one is reused 15 to 20 times), 98% of packaging and 83% of cans. Sleeman also has a good record on limiting emissions and wastewater discharge. Leads this industry group in employee relations and has excellent health benefits and safety-management programs. Has formal employment equity policies, but marks off for no women on its board or in senior management.

Vincor International [53]

This producer and marketer of wines has strong corporate governance provisions, including a code of conduct for officers and directors (a majority of its directors are independent). Scores well in health and safety, but has the weakest employee diversity record in the group.

Molson [51]

A leader in community relations, Molson donated about $3.5 million to charity in 2003, or more than 2% of its pretax profits. Lags behind others on corporate governance. Has the least democratic share structure-the Molson family has control through multiple-voting shares-and the highest executive compensation.

Corby Distilleries [46]

One-third of directors and senior managers are women, including president and CEO Krystyna Hoeg. Reporting on social and environmental issues is notably poor. Corporate governance impaired by a dual-class share structure.

Cott [44]

Above average in employee relations and diversity; poorest in this group in corporate governance. Social and environmental reporting is weak, and government environmental standards are not always met.

Saputo [44]

Poor environmental audit practices and performance record. Several violations of government standards over the past five years, mainly for exceeding effluent-discharge permit limits.

Maple Leaf Foods [43]

The worst environmental compliance in the group and a poor labour relations record. Strong on corporate governance. One of the few companies in the group to participate in the national Voluntary Challenge and Registry program on climate change.

The Industry

What it's doing right There are isolated successes in some sub-groups-such as the brewers' bottle and packaging reuse and recycling programs-and in individual companies.

Still needs work Some of the companies in this group face environmental and labour relations issues, many related to health and safety. American competition, in particular, has put downward pressure on wages and weakened job security at some companies, leading to confrontations between unions and management.

Packaging is a major environmental problem. While the brewers are reusing and recycling, the soft drink industry has shifted away from returnable bottles and aluminum cans, and has increased its use of plastic containers, which have a much lower recovery value than cans and are far harder to recycle.

For some companies, reducing emissions remains a challenge. This is particularly true of Maple Leaf and Saputo, the two food producers in this group. Last year, Ontario's Environment Ministry charged Maple Leaf's Rothsay Rendering subsidiary with 16 infractions in connection with discharges of wastewater into a stream that flows through conservation area trout ponds near Hamilton.

The few companies that offer environmental reporting do so in a brief and vague manner.

Bottom Line

Over all, this is a motley crew. Some companies have taken modest steps forward, but others appear to have little interest in the social and environmental issues associated with their operations.

Food Distribution

George Weston/ Loblaw [45]

Performs relatively well in employee relations-having the best benefits and diversity record in this industry group-and a mostly decent relationship with unions. Weston also has a strong environmental management system. But product safety and labelling are problems for both Loblaw and parent company Weston, which is also a large food producer. In fact, Weston is a leading North American producer of farmed salmon, and its aquaculture and seafood operations have paid $1.2 million in environmental penalties over the past five years.

Canada Safeway [44]

The only company in the group to publish a public environmental report, but the chain's relationship with unionized workers is the poorest.

Metro [44]

An average performer in most areas. Strong on diversity, with a diversity plan at its Econogros division and a higher-than-average level of female representation (three out of 13) on its board of directors.

A&P [43]

Women hold four of the board's nine seats-a high ratio for any industry. Environmental performance is mediocre, and A&P's overall health and safety record is the poorest in this group.

Empire/Sobeys [43]

Good corporate governance despite a dual-class share structure with multiple-voting shares that maintain the Sobey family's control.

Poor relationship with its unionized workers.

Alimentation Couche-Tard [38]

Weak in corporate governance and environmental issues, with no reports of any environmental management system or any initiatives to reduce or recycle waste.

The Industry

WHAT IT'S DOING RIGHT All retailers in the group have responded to public concern over food ingredients and the environment by introducing items such as organic produce, recycled paper products and less environmentally harmful detergents. Also, some chains have a strong record on employee diversity and promoting women.

STILL NEEDS WORK Controversies over ingredients and product labelling continue to dog the industry, particularly the issue of genetically modified foods. Loblaw has been the focus of public controversy over forbidding suppliers to label products as "GM-free." The company says that, in the absence of government standards, the claims may be false. George Weston also faced heat as a food producer recently because of its Heritage Salmon subsidiary, which produces 1 in 5 farmed salmon in North America. Environmentalists worry about the impact of salmon farming on the ocean and on wild salmon. Also, a recent study reported significantly higher-and potentially harmful-concentrations of organochlorines in farmed salmon than in wild ones. Other environmental worries in the sector include excessive and non-recyclable packaging and waste management.

Employee relations are a perennial problem for grocery chains, especially around working conditions and health and safety. Competition from non-food retailers is intensifying. Downward pressure on wages, benefits and job security is increasing as well. Supermarkets are also relying more and more on part-time workers, whose wages and benefits are lower than those of full-timers.

Human rights in developing countries are also a growing concern with consumers, but companies aren't addressing the issue yet. All the supermarkets stock coffee, sugar and other products from countries in which working conditions are poor. Higher-priced "fair trade" versions of many products are available, but none of the chains has committed itself to them, although at least one Canadian corporation-Van Houtte Inc.-offers "fair trade" coffee.

Bottom Line

None of the companies can be called a corporate social responsibility leader. Issues related to consumer choice-such as GM foods-are likely to intensify in the future, and these companies need to take more initiative.

Forestry

Tembec [58]

Vows to have all its forestry operations certified by the Forest Stewardship Council, an international body that includes industry and environmental groups, by 2005. As of last December, more than 20% of Tembec's forests were certified. Some of the company's pulp and paper operations still have problems complying with environmental regulations. (More on page 66.)

Nexfor [55]

Became the first major Canadian forest products company to publish an environmental report (1990). Includes a comprehensive section on the environment and health and safety in its annual report, and posts information on its website. Still, the reporting lacks detail on community relations.

Cascades [54]

Through its 45% ownership of Boralex Inc., this pulp and paper company is involved in alternative energy production, including wind and wood-residue thermal power. But Cascades' environmental reporting is meagre.

Weldwood [54]

Has a comprehensive code of business ethics that applies to all employees. The code includes core company values and outlines how employees should treat each other, customers, suppliers and communities in which the company operates.

Norske Skog [51]

Searches of government records show no convictions or financial penalties for violating environmental regulations at any time over the past five years.

Canfor [49]

Relatively large number of women at high levels-three of 14 directors and three of 13 officers are female. However, Canfor does not have an employment equity policy and has not implemented formal programs to encourage the advancement of women, visible minorities and other under-represented groups.

Domtar [49]

Signed an agreement with World Wildlife Fund Canada in November, 2003, in which Domtar agreed to certify all of its forests and mills under Forest Stewardship Council standards. Over the past five years, government records show Domtar has paid the most in health and safety penalties of any company in this industry group-more than $300,000.

Abitibi-Consolidated [47]

The largest recycler of newspapers and magazines in North America, and the largest newspaper recycler in the world. Still embroiled in a long dispute with the Grassy Narrows First Nation over the impact of logging near Kenora, Ont.

West Fraser Timber [39]

None of the company's 10 directors or 11 officers is female.

Lack of disclosure also contributed to the company's low score.

The Industry

What it's doing right The industry has recognized the need to harvest forests in a more sustainable manner. Some companies have committed to the rigorous Forest Stewardship Council standards for practices, developed by a broad international coalition that, in Canada, includes Greenpeace and Tembec. The standards also have support from some retailers. The industry, including the pulp and paper producers, is getting better at recycling.

Still needs work Most companies still choose an easier road by agreeing to meet guidelines developed either by Canada's provincial forestry ministers (Canadian Standards Association) or the U.S. timber trade association (Sustainable Forestry Initiative). Many environmental groups and other organizations say those guidelines aren't strong enough. Companies are also moving into more environmentally sensitive areas to get new timber. Compared with other resource producers, major forestry companies have a poor record on consulting local communities and First Nations. Only a few have formal consultation processes, and benefits-sharing agreements are rare.

Pulp mills have made some progress in limiting pollution, but too many still have problems meeting current standards. Mills are also insatiable freshwater users, and can seriously harm fish habitats by reducing water levels or altering temperatures.

Bottom Line

The industry has made progress toward developing a more sustainable business, but there's a lack of consensus on the appropriate environmental certification standards.

Insurance

Manulife Financial [61]

Issues detailed reports of its charitable giving, including names of some funded projects and organizations. Score suffers because of high compensation for CEO Dominic D'Alessandro, who received $8.8 million (including stock options) in 2002, highest among companies in this group.

Industrial Alliance [59]

Corporate governance record is strong. Thirteen of 15 directors are independent. Has formal code of conduct.

Sun Life [54] Donated 1% of pretax profits to charity in 2002, tied with SSQ for the highest level in this group. Total donations were $10.7 million.

Desjardins Financial [53]

The only company in the group that has not split the jobs of chairman and CEO.

SSQ, Financial [49]

Has a higher proportion of women senior managers than other companies in this group.

Great-West Life [46]

Tied with Desjardins and Manulife for the best employee diversity programs in this group. However, Great-West and its London Life subsidiary have been hit the hardest by lawsuits related to policies that promised so-called vanishing premiums. Both have also paid fines and settlements over disputed insurance claims.

Maritime Life [44]

Committed to donating 1% of average pretax profit to charity, the same percentage as Sun Life and SSQ, but doesn't provide actual donations figures.

The Industry

What it's doing right Relative to most other industries, insurers have a high proportion of women in management and on their boards, along with good employment equity practices. Unlike the banks, the insurers are not subject to the federal Employment Equity Act, which requires annual reports on progress toward achieving a representative workforce. But many insurers have formal policies and programs in place.

Like the banks, several Canadian insurance companies are large enough that they're required to issue annual public accountability statements under federal rules that apply to financial institutions. In those statements, the insurers must outline the economic and community impact of their operations, including total charitable donations and taxes paid. Within this group, that includes Maritime Life, Sun Life and Great-West. Manulife and Sun Life also include information on environmental issues, even though it's not required.

Still needs work One big potential problem for insurers is their loans or investments in businesses and countries with low social or environmental standards. Like banks, insurers aren't required to disclose their investment and loan portfolios. But, at least so far, the insurers haven't been grilled as hard as the banks.

The insurers aren't moving very quickly on their own. No company in this group has endorsed the United Nations Environmental Program's Statement of Environmental Commitment for the Insurance Industry or adopted the Equator Principles on environmental and social risk in project financing.

Bottom Line

Like the banks, insurers have relatively strong employment equity practices. But much of the social and environmental impact of their operations depends on their loan and investment portfolios. More disclosure is needed.

Mining

Alcan [61]

A leading recycler of aluminum worldwide: In 2001 and 2002, recycled aluminum from consumers made up nearly 40% of the metal processed by Alcan's plants. Recycling saves energy as well. Alcan has also set company targets for reducing climate-warming greenhouse gas emissions and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (a carcinogen).

Noranda [55]

Longest history in the group of reporting on environmental and health and safety issues, including public reports on fines and non-compliance with regulations. Falconbridge, Noranda's 60%-owned nickel subsidiary, aims to reduce wastewater from production by 50% by 2005. However, Noranda shares the poorest score in the group, with Teck Cominco, for overall health and safety.

Teck Cominco [50]

A leader in the group in community consultation initiatives, such as a program in Trail, B.C., to reduce children's exposure to lead. Has paid the most in environmental penalties among group companies over the past five years, including some related to tailings and fuel spills at Canadian and U.S. operations.

Inco [46] Has significantly improved its reporting on environmental and health and safety performance. However, Inco is Canada's largest emitter of airborne nickel, including sulphur dioxide and a significant emitter of other pollutants. Also has a poor community relations record at home and abroad. New Caledonia is one recent trouble spot-local Kanaks fear the environmental impact of Inco's Goro nickel project and say the company has not consulted with them.

Fording Canadian Coal Trust [38]

The only company in the group that does not publish a public report on its environmental performance.

The Industry

WHAT IT'S DOING RIGHT Most large mining companies have responded to public pressure by trying to reduce pollution and implementing formal environmental, health and safety management systems and programs. Almost all of these companies issue reports on these issues and community relations performance.

STILL NEEDS WORK The environment, community relations and health and safety remain sore spots. Too often, companies address these issues only when they're required to by public pressure or government policies.

The industry has left hundreds of hazardous abandoned mines. Taxpayers often have to pick up the tab for cleanups, and governments are now under more pressure to demand financial guarantees from companies for reclamation costs.

Despite some improvements, many companies still tend to dig in their heels when dealing with local communities. This can backfire. Inco, for example, has had its reputation tarnished by a bitter fight with residents of Port Colborne, Ont., over elevated nickel levels in soil. Boliden Inc., a Canadian and Swedish company, had to spend $107 million (U.S.) to clean up after a tailings pond from a zinc mine in Spain burst and sent toxic sludge over about 2,500 acres of farmland and countryside in 1998.

Many ore deposits are in countries with poor human rights records-some in war zones. Companies are under pressure to adopt management systems that address those issues, as well as bribery and corruption.

Bottom Line

Mining, by definition, is unsustainable. The industry needs to reinvent itself by moving away from primary metal extraction, adopting more environmentally friendly practices and placing more emphasis on metal recycling. This won't happen any time soon.

Oil and Gas

Suncor Energy [66]

Established itself as a Canadian and world leader in 2000 by committing $100 million over five years to green energy, including investments in large wind power projects in Saskatchewan and southern Alberta.

Very supportive of aboriginal and M{Zcaron}tis communities, including programs for small business, employment and education. Scores poorly, however, against competitors on greenhouse gas emissions.

Petro-Canada [63]

The best performer in this group in terms of greenhouse gas emissions management systems. In December, Petrocan extended a five-year, $33-million partnership to help Ottawa-based Iogen Corp. develop a commercially viable means of turning corn and cereal into ethanol.

Imperial Oil [53]

Known as Esso at the pumps, Imperial has moved from being one of the worst performers with respect to sulphur levels in gasoline to the best. It's the first Canadian company to comply with federal regulations to produce low-sulphur fuel at refineries by 2005. However, Imperial has been slow to clean up contaminated sites, often fighting legal battles rather than complying with orders immediately.

Shell Canada [53]

The glass ceiling has been shattered at Shell by CEO Linda Cook and CFO Cathy Williams. Has problems with environmental compliance-

government records show about $600,000 in penalties over the past five years.

Husky Energy [49]

Only company in the group not to release environmental or sustainability

reports. Like Imperial Oil, Husky has no women senior officers.

The Industry

WHAT IT'S DOING RIGHT Producing fossil fuels and burning them is inherently harmful to the environment, but most oil and gas producers are at least trying to reduce the damage. Suncor, in particular, is going the extra mile by making major investments in alternative energy sources. Also, in 1999, the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers launched its stewardship initiative, which encourages companies to improve their environmental and health and safety performance. The association publishes industry-wide data on several key indicators and has established performance benchmarks for companies.

STILL NEEDS WORK Current and planned oil sands operations in northern Alberta are among the most energy-intensive-and thus greenhouse-gas-intensive-ways of getting oil from the ground. Expansion could make it more difficult for Canada to meet targets under the Kyoto Protocol.

Conventional oil and gas reserves across the western provinces are waning, so the industry is looking to develop new sources in the Arctic and off the coast of British Columbia, where the province is asking Ottawa to lift a 30-year moratorium on drilling. In both areas, this could disrupt delicate ecosystems. It will also require negotiations with local native communities. In B.C., the Haida First Nation has launched a legal action claiming ownership of the Queen Charlotte Islands and surrounding waters.

Companies are also looking overseas, where Petro-Canada, in particular, has greatly increased production. Human rights may become an issue in some countries. The saga of Talisman Energy, which sold its interests in war-torn Sudan after years of controversy, shows how badly things can go wrong.

Bottom Line

The industry's basic business will inevitably damage habitats, generate harmful emissions and exacerbate climate change. Resource extraction is also, by nature, unsustainable. Companies have been generally unwilling to face these realities, but they must now use profits to aggressively speed the transition to alternative and renewable energy sources.

Retail

Hudson's Bay [60]

A leader in this industry group in corporate governance, environment and addressing sweatshop labour issues. Has programs to increase energy efficiency and improve employees' environmental awareness.

Has a strong human-rights code of conduct for suppliers and the best mechanisms to monitor compliance. The Bay now issues an extensive annual corporate social responsibility (CSR) report.

Sears Canada [52]

Code of ethics and buying policies address human rights better than most companies in the group, but mechanisms to monitor compliance lag. Does not issue public human rights or CSR reports. Customer record has been tarnished by recent Competition Bureau allegations of deceptive advertising.

Rates high on corporate governance and the environment, having implemented energy efficiency and waste reduction programs.

Canadian Tire [49]

Stands out for environmental performance in recycling and waste reduction programs. Strong employee benefits. Weak on corporate governance because of its dual-class share structure.

Shoppers Drug Mart [43]

A leader in corporate donations, giving almost 4% of pretax profits in fiscal 2001 and 2002. Worst score in the group for corporate governance-just three of 12 directors are independent.

Costco [42]

Scores above average on employee relations, but has the worst environmental compliance record in this group.

Forzani [42]

Strong programs in employee benefits and health and safety. Like any major sporting goods retailer, Forzani has exposure to labour and human rights issues through its suppliers. Does not report any initiatives in this area.

Jean Coutu [42]

Has the strongest female representation in this group on its board of directors (five out of 16) and in senior management (four out of 17), but scores relatively poorly in employee programs and benefits.

Rona [36]

Performs reasonably well in corporate governance but poorly in other areas. Lack of reporting a key issue.

The Industry

What it's doing right It's hard for retailers to avoid the charge that suppliers, particularly those in developing countries, use sweatshop labour. In response to those concerns and others, Hudson's Bay now publishes an annual corporate social responsibility report. As well, some retailers have modest management systems in place to deal with those issues.

STILL NEEDS WORK Labour problems among manufacturers in developing countries are still widespread, including low wages, forced overtime, and poor health and safety standards. Campaigns by labour groups and shareholder activists have targeted clothing and shoe manufacturers, but abuses are also common in other industries. Four of the eight companies in this group-Forzani, Jean Coutu, Rona and Shoppers Drug Mart-do not report having policies or monitoring systems for suppliers.

Canadian retailers that have systems in place aren't doing as well as some of their international counterparts. Companies such as Nike, the Gap, Reebok and Adidas have been embroiled in controversies in the past and are now more responsive on these issues. Hudson's Bay has been criticized for cutting ties with a Lesotho-based clothing supplier because of labour rights abuses, rather than trying to help improve conditions, as other major retailers have done.

Customer issues (including product safety and marketing practices), employee relations and environmental issues can be costly and contentious for retailers as well.

Bottom Line

Some retailers have addressed human rights and other issues with suppliers, but even the best performers in this group lag behind their international counterparts. Half the group appears to have done nothing at all. Much progress is needed.

Technology

Hewlett-Packard [75]

A world leader in developing systems to measure and improve the environmental impact of products and processes. Has developed criteria to measure its suppliers' performances in areas such as the environment and health and labour practices. Will soon require suppliers to report annually on compliance. A strong contingent of women on the board and in senior management, including CEO Carly Fiorina. Policies on suppliers' labour practices still fall short of those of leaders in the shoe and clothing industries.

Siemens [66]

Publishes a detailed annual corporate responsibility report on citizenship and the environment. Also has comprehensivle policies and programs to in place to promote the advancement of women and minorities. Progress has been marred by complaints of sexual discrimination at a plant in Virginia.

Nortel Networks [61]

Has implemented employment equity and workplace harassment policies in all operations. Launched its Affirmative Procurement Program in 1980 to encourage subcontracting to minority- and women-owned businesses.

Xerox [61]

Has the highest level of charitable giving in this industry group and received the top score for waste management. In 2002, Xerox treated 97% of hazardous waste through recycling, treatment or fuel blending.

Celestica [52]

Ranks among the worst in this group for environmental reporting.

Does not publish an environmental report.

General Electric [48]

Environmental reporting is among the best in this group-every week, each GE facility completes an environmental and health and safety checklist. Audits suppliers as well. Health and safety record is poor-SEC filings show GE has paid more than $3 million (U.S.) in penalties worldwide over the past five years.

Bombardier [44]

Receives some marks for manufacturing rail equipment, which is less harmful to the environment than cars and trucks. Government records show more than $575,000 in penalties over the past five years for health and safety violations.

Rogers Wireless [42]

Environmental management systems are limited, and the company does not publish an environmental report or provide information on its website.

ATI Technologies [39]

Scores poorly on corporate governance. Share dilution rate from the company stock option plan is the highest in this group. K.Y. Ho, chairman and CEO, faces an investigation by the Ontario Securities Commission on allegations of insider trading, and ATI recently settled U.S. shareholder class-action lawsuits.

The Industry

What it's doing right Manufacturing and running tech equipment often involves large amounts of energy and water, and hundreds of hazardous substances. Disposing of waste and old equipment can be very difficult. Yet the multinationals that top this group are global leaders in environmental stewardship and in reporting. Hewlett-Packard, in particular, is trying to minimize damage at all stages of a product's life cycle.

HP and other top companies in the group are also making progress on employee diversity, labour practices and other social responsibility issues, and are issuing reports.

Still needs work Most big tech companies have exposure to human rights issues through their own overseas operations and through suppliers. Only a few leaders in the industry are addressing them. So far, they have avoided the public protests directed at clothing and shoe manufacturers such as the Gap and Nike. All of them can expect increased outside pressure to disclose and verify their practices.

Aside from Nortel Networks, Canadian companies in the group score poorly on several indicators. This is due to a lack of programs and policies, as well as a lack of reporting at several companies.

Bottom Line

The best companies in the tech sector are global leaders in environmental stewardship and reporting on social responsibility issues. But the laggards in the group are far behind.

urn:contentItem:5XXY-51P1-DYX1-V1XF-00000-00Corporate: Special Report: Whatâ s next for tech after its â decade horribilisâ ?2020-01-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:42ZLexisNexisCorporate: Special Report: Whatâ s next for tech after its â decade horribilisâ ?Assif Shameen

At the beginning of the just-ended decade, for the most part, technology was seen as a force for good. Ten years on, platforms such as Google and Facebook are being mocked for their callousness on data privacy and the spread of misinformation. The New York Times described the 2010s as â the decade tech lost its wayâ . Ironically, the decade had begun with the â Arab Springâ and social media was hailed as an enabler of democracy and freedom of expression. As the curtain fell on techâ s â decade horribilisâ , there is again hope that it might yet deliver on its promise.

Here are some of the things that are likely to define the next 10 years in tech.

Regulation

Around the world, regulators are taking a hard look at the business practices of Big Tech firms such as social media supremo Facebook, iPhone-maker Apple, e-commerce powerhouse Amazon.com, software behemoth Microsoft and search giant Googleâ s owner Alphabet, or the so-called FAAMA. (An older acronym FAANG, which included streaming giant Netflix, is now seen as outdated as Walt Disney, Apple and Amazon have been chipping away at its lead). Techâ s Big Five now have a combined market capitalisation of over US$5.04 trillion. Over the past decade, the total market value of the five has risen sevenfold. Yet, tech honchos were not busy popping champagne corks this past holiday season to celebrate how much value they have created. Tech giants are in the crosshairs for sucking everything into their vortex, abusing their powers, collecting too much information about us without our approval and then monetising our data to boost their already hefty bottom lines.

Detractors have dubbed the top five as unregulated monopolies. Google has a near-monopoly on search-based advertising. With its control of Instagram and WhatsApp, Facebook is the dominant social media platform accused of spreading disinformation, weaponising racial hatred, using voter suppression tactics and is increasingly seen as a threat to democracy. It is not just left wing US presidential candidates who want Google and Facebook on a tighter leash. The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC), Department of Justice, several US states as well as congressional committees have initiated inquiries into their anti-competitive behaviour. Moreover, the European Union has imposed US$7 billion in fines on Google over the past four years and more penalties are likely.

Google and Facebook algorithms have destroyed the media industry by soaking up a huge portion of global advertising with their hammerlock on the market through programmatic ads. Amazon has disrupted retail, cloud services and logistics, yet still thrives on selling unsafe products on its platform while using its near-monopolistic power to strong-arm competitors and suppliers. FTC is looking into Facebookâ s acquisition of Instagram and WhatsApp and there have also been calls to break up Google, which acquired YouTube for a song a decade ago.

Breaking up the tech giants will not be easy. It could take up to a decade, perhaps longer, to level the playing field, even if there was political will. Action is needed because the tech giants continue to stifle competition and innovation. If we want to see the sort of value creation in tech over the next decade that we saw over the last, regulators need to put their foot down and create an environment where a thousand unicorns, or private tech firms valued over a billion dollars, bloom. It would be wise not to bet against big tech. While it is possible that one or two tech giants might falter, or indeed break up, the rest will become even bigger and more powerful.

Splinternet

Despite the recent trade truce between Washington and Beijing, the ongoing US-China cold war and the battle for tech supremacy will eventually lead to two separate technologies â " one dominated by China and the other by companies in the Western world. Unfortunately, the rest of the world will have a stark choice: Back one or the other. Will Asians use Googleâ s Android and Appleâ s iOS or the new mobile operating system that Huawei is working on? Will Malaysians, Singaporeans and Indonesians search on Google or on Baidu, or use WeChatâ s search engine? Will they order goods from one of Alibabaâ s platform companies or Amazon? Will they listen to music on Spotify, Apple Music or switch to Tencent Music? Will they use ApplePay, Google Pay or Alibabaâ s Alipay or Tencentâ s WeChat Pay? Will they use Microsoft Windows or Appleâ s MacOS or a Chinese operating system to run their PCs? Will they tweet on Twitter or Sina Weibo, watch videos on YouTube or Youku Tudou?

Washington also wants to prevent Chinese firms from buying US-sourced technology components, investing in US tech firms as well as exporting its tech products to the US. Beijing is not taking it lying down. It recently launched a US$20 billion fund to support Chinese independence in a range of manufacturing technologies to complement another US$20 billion fund to boost development in semiconductors. Chinaâ s decision to consciously decouple from American technology, building separate domestic manufacturing capacity for components it previously imported and securing its own supply chains only reinforces techâ s balkanisation, which in turn could lead to derating of global tech giants. Chinaâ s tech ecosystem would look like a beautiful bonsai to investors, confined mostly within its borders. The Alibabas and Tencents of the world will be derated, as will many American tech firms that can sell almost everywhere except in the worldâ s second-largest market.

The rise and rise of surveillance

Like it or not, you are being watched and all sorts of data about you is being gathered through your smartphone, watch, tablet, desktop browsing, car, shopping habits, travels, financial transactions as well as visits to the doctor, restaurants and theatres. Every time you walk into a mall, office building, train station, airport, school or hospital, or walk on a pavement downtown, your image is being recorded. Soon you would be able to board a plane or train or watch a movie in a cinema or a soccer match in a stadium without a physical ticket because cameras will recognise that you have already paid for your ticket since your image, itinerary and payment data is already stored somewhere in the cloud.

Shops would have your entire credit history and whether you can afford the product you are browsing; they will treat you differently from another less-credit-worthy customer. It is spooky and it will get worse even in some of the most liberal countries that pride themselves in protecting privacy. The debate around surveillance and privacy will only get louder over the next 10 years but we are too far along in the surveillance economy to turn back.

In the final years of the just-ended decade, among the big tech themes were artificial intelligence, machine learning and deep learning, digital payments, blockchain and the cloud-based subscription economy, particularly within the software and services space, though it has been spreading to hardware. Ten years from now, few of us will still have our own smartphones or cars. We will just take out a subscription to a car or phone service that gives us access to the hardware. We are likely to see more traction on AI and digital payments in the new decade but do not bet against incumbents such as the big banks. JP Morgan, which pooh-poohed bitcoin two years ago, is working on its own stable coin, JPM Coin.

At end-2019, there were over 410 unicorns worldwide. New crops of unicorns will come not just from firms in blockchain, AI or payments but also from firms in 5G-enabled Internet of Things such as driverless cars and remote robotic surgery. Emerging unicorns might also include pioneers in quantum computing, which use supercomputers equipped with advanced processing powers as well as edge computing, which enables connected devices like driverless cars to process data closer to where it is created â " or the â edgeâ . Essentially, edge computing will provide driverless cars with an alternative to sending data to a far-away remote server or a centralised â cloudâ for processing. As edge computing gets traction, driverless cars will become a reality sooner than we expect.

The recent implosion of co-working unicorn WeWork will likely have far-reaching consequences for who gets funded and how long unicorns can stay private in the new decade. Valued at over US$49 billion by its venture capital investors, WeWork sought a listing in October at a valuation of between US$75 billion and US$100 billion. By the time investors read through its pre-IPO prospectus, or S1 filing, they were looking at a firm that was just weeks away from bankruptcy. It was bailed out by its largest investor, Japanâ s SoftBank Group, and is currently valued at just over US$7.5 billion.

The lesson we learnt from the WeWork saga is that public markets are far better in separating the wheat from the chaff than a handful of VCs in the private markets. SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son became the worldâ s richest person at the height of the 2000 tech boom by overpaying for tech start-ups. When the bubble burst, Son, whose net worth declined 95% in the aftermath, spent the next decade nursing his wounds until he struck gold with a US$20 million investment in Chinese e-commerce pioneer Alibaba Group Holding, which turned into US$120 billion, or a 6,000-fold gain. In the aftermath of the WeWork debacle, it might take Son more than just a decade to get his mojo back.

We are also likely to see a bigger push towards the democratisation of investing, or enabling more investors to partake in the next tech boom. That means free online stock trading for everyone, even if you are not selling your data to the brokerage in return. It also means trading in fractional shares so you can just invest US$100 in Â­Amazon.com without worrying about the fact that you have to fork out US$1,880 for just one share. Regulators should not prevent you from buying what you want or when you want. Another trend that will catch on in the new decade is direct listings. More firms such as Spotify, Slack and Airbnb will choose to list directly instead of taking the traditional IPO route. A direct listing is not just a cheaper IPO alternative and not just for firms that do not want to raise new money. It can also be used by firms that are raising money as part of the listing process.

After the nightmare of the just-ended decade, tech desperately wants to get its act together and deliver on its promise â " not just as an agent of change and disruption but also as a force for good.

Assif Shameen is a technology writer based in North America

urn:contentItem:5W47-G6S1-JCF0-400F-00000-00Corporate: Tech: ATA.ONE offers cheap airfares to fill empty seats2019-05-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:42ZLexisNexisCorporate: Tech: ATA.ONE offers cheap airfares to fill empty seatsKang Siew Li

Mobile apps have been transforming the travel experience for airlines and passengers alike over the past decade or so, from booking tickets to online check-ins.

Now, there is an app that lets passengers seek bargain airfares by bidding for last-minute leftover seats while helping airlines fill empty seats at the same time.

And if talks between the UK-based technology company that created it and Malaysia-based airlines are successful, it may soon be available for download here.

ATA.ONE Ltd managing director Kresimir Budinski says the company has approached Malaysiaâ s three key airlines â " Malaysia Airlines Bhd, AirAsia Group Bhd and Malindo Airways Sdn Bhd â " with the hope of securing them as its first airline customers in Southeast Asia.

It is still early days but he says the talks have been positive.

â Southeast Asia is for us a very interesting market because it has a large population of more than 650 million. We established a subsidiary in Kuala Lumpur in end-January to help promote and market our solution in this part of the world,â he tells The Edge in an interview.

The ATA.ONE app is currently only available in Europe and the Middle East. The company has four airline customers to date â " Croatia Airlines, Montenegro Airlines, Iberia and Azerbaijan Airlines â " and the app is connected to their inventory (unfilled seats).

â We have approached 50 other airlines such as Qatar Airways, Emirates, Singapore Airlines, Japan Airlines and Brunei Airlines to come onboard our air ticket distribution platform. It does not matter if they are low-cost or full-service carriers,â Budinski says.

About 2.2 million seats are left unsold every day around the world, he points out. â For airlines, empty seats mean lost revenue. With ATA.ONE, we can help them sell all their unsold or distressed inventory.â

The main concern among airlines, he notes, is that ATA.ONEâ s solution might cannibalise their current sales.

â The solution is, in fact, attracting new customers that they never have had before. The airlines also determine the minimum price they are willing to accept for the unsold seats, as well as the number of seats and flights they would like to offer on our distribution platform, so there will be no cannibalisation,â he explains.

The solution also offers airlines the ability to block any of their passengers from accessing the online platform. â The bidding rules are fully controlled by the airlines,â says Budinski.

The platform is a â low-risk, free solutionâ for airlines as it is fully automated, he asserts. â The seats are only sold at prices that are within the airlineâ s acceptable profit margins, and there is no cost to airlines or passengers until a match occurs and e-tickets are issued.â

To use the ATA.ONE distribution platform, airlines first determine the minimum price they are willing to accept for seats that remain unsold 24 or 48 hours prior to a flightâ s departure.

As for passengers, they just have to download the ATA.ONE app on their mobile phones and register, says Budinski.

â Once they have completed the registration process, they can search for the desired destination, airline, travel dates and budget. Upon entering all the information, they just need to place a bid. If it is a winning bid, payment is done automatically and the booking code is received directly from the airline, 24 to 48 hours prior to the planned departure.

â This booking code will be used for web check-in. However, the booking code does not guarantee passengers a seat on the flight they bought because it is still up to the airline. That can happen even if they buy a [physical] ticket. The thing is, not everybody turns up for every flight,â he says.

According to him, fares purchased via ATA.ONE app can be 40% to 60% cheaper than a regular airline ticket. Each time a seat is sold through an ATA.ONE bid, the passenger pays a small commission to the company.

ATA.ONE expects to break even by June. â We need to sell about 300 seats per day to break even. We did 2,000 successful bids in October to December last year,â says Budinski, who has more than 25 years of experience in the aviation industry and business in general.

He founded the company with four others â " Sandra Mikuli, Ivan Janovi, Sasa Pavolovi and Jiri Marek. Budinski is the largest shareholder with a 76% stake with the remaining 24% equity interest split among 30 investors from 13 countries, including the four co-founders.

He says ATA.ONE was established in 2015 with Â£50,000 in funds. It started with an idea to create a tool that would help airlines to sell unsold seats through a bidding process at the last minute.

â We spoke to a couple of airlines and all were positive about the idea. During the first two years, we spent time travelling around Europe, the Middle East and East Asia, visiting airlines and explaining our business idea without any product. That was the toughest part of this business â " to convince the airlinesâ revenue managers that the ATA.ONE solution would not cannibalise their existing sales channel,â Budinski says.

Between November 2017 and February 2018, the company developed a proof of concept to test its idea, during which it attracted 80,000 website visits and 10,000 registered users to its bidding platform.

â That was another sign [for us] to continue the solution to full development, which was completed in August 2018. At the time, we had already secured Croatia Airlines, Montenegro Airlines, Iberia and Azerbaijan Airlines as our trial airline customers,â says Budinski, a Croatian.

The platform saw interest from airlines in Southeast Asia last December.

The company is looking to raise Â£5 million to Â£10 million from new investors in the third quarter of the year to expand its reach globally.

Budinski says he is willing to pare down his stake in ATA.ONE to 51%.

â In 2020, we intend to expand our platform to cover North and South America. We are leaving that to the last even though it is a major market as there are a lot more regulations there,â he adds.

In the long term, he is looking at an initial public offering in 2021 as an exit strategy or to sell the business to a larger tech rival. â There are three big tech companies in the world which are monitoring our development,â he says.

Based on a third-party valuation carried out recently, the company is worth Â£14 million, he adds.

urn:contentItem:5S63-MPN1-DYX1-V0RG-00000-00Corporate: Tech: Why payments will help drive Chinaâ s Big Tech2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:42ZLexisNexisCorporate: Tech: Why payments will help drive Chinaâ s Big TechAssif Shameen

2017 was the Year of China Tech. Global investors helped drive Chinese tech stocks 70% higher last year, with shares of the two internet giants, Tencent Holdings and Alibaba Group Holding, more than doubling as they chased high-growth tech plays. More recently, though, investors have been less enamoured with the duo as well asÂ Baidu,Â Â­JD.comÂ and other Chinese tech stocks. From their peak in late January to the trough earlier this month, large Chinese tech stocks were down nearly 15%, with Â­Alibaba 19% lower. Although they rebounded recently, most are way below their January peak.

So, what has changed? Is it just the sentiment towards Chinese stocks in the aftermath of US President Donald Trumpâ s tough talk on trade and tariffs as well as his vow to clamp down on intellectual property violations by Chinese companies? Or are fundamentals, such as margin pressures and a slower pace of earnings growth from the robust levels of last year, a factor? â It is only natural that there was some profit-Â­taking given how well Chinese internet stocks have performed over the past two years,â Â­Oliver Cox, portfolio manager for JPMorgan Â­Asset Management in Hong Kong, who runs the firmâ s Pacific Technology Fund, tellsÂ The Edge SingaporeÂ in a recent interview.Â 

China tech stocks are not alone in feeling suddenly unloved by global investors. Trumpâ s tweets about e-commerce giant Amazon.com, the sight of Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg being forced to testify before the US Congress and Washingtonâ s attempt to regulate search giant Googleâ s parent Alphabet have all weighed on the global tech sector. Yet, while an aggressive pushback against the erosion of privacy as well as monetisation of data in the aftermath of recent Facebook revelations has impacted US tech giants, Chinese internet firms are continuing to grow at a much faster pace than their US peers and are also able to harness the data more powerfully.

To be sure, although US internet giants and their Chinese counterparts may share similar business models, their medium- to longer-term outlooks could not be more different. In many ways, Alibaba and Tencent have an advantage over their developed-market peers. For one thing, Chinaâ s population is more ready to embrace new technology without fretting about privacy. Moreover, the countryâ s regulatory environment is not only benign, but Beijing has been a big cheerleader for its home-grown chamÂ­pions whom it is keen to nurture as global tech leaders. In addition to Alibaba and its ilk being able to collect more data more freely, as China catches up in artificial intelligence and eventually takes the lead, their ability to monetise whatever they collect, including data on their customersâ health and finances, makes them more formidable players in e-commerce, search, gaming, financial technology and robotics.

Chinese internet players have long lived in the shadow of global giants such as Â­Amazon, Google and social network operator Facebook. â Investors have consistently underestimated growth in consumer demand as well as in e-commerce or online retailing or gaming or even search advertising in China, which have all ended up growing far faster than what the market anticipated,â says Cox. They have also underestimated the Chinese giantsâ ability to chart their own course to the top. Tencent and Alibaba are ranked among the top six tech companies in the world by market value.

Eighty-five per cent of people in China still buy from physical stores. Having cornered 15% of the total market, Alibaba and Tencent are now going aggressively after offline bricks-and-mortar retail. Over the past two years, they have spent about US$20 billion (RM77.7 billion) buying offline retailers as they seek to extend their control of O2O, or online-to-offline, Â­retailing by pulling in shoppers who buy online from retailers with a physical presence. More often than not, Chinese consumers are using Alipay or Tenpay to pay for their online or offline purchases. Aside from digital payments, Alibaba and Tencent are pouring money into logistics and delivery as well as mobile digital payments. These investments complement their core franchises, Cox says.

Still bleeding on payments

One area that has long been touted as a key driver for China tech plays is payments. China has leapfrogged into a cashless society. Most people pay for coffee, food, indeed even roadside chestnuts, by scanning QR codes on their smartphones. iResearch expects digital payments in China to grow 66% this year. Both AliÂ­babaâ s 33%-owned affiliate Ant Financial and Tencentâ s 30%-owned financial arm WeBank were expected to list later this year but analysts say those IPOs have now been pushed to next year. Ant and its mobile and online payment system Â­Alipay now boast a little more than half of Chinaâ s US$17 trillion payments market with Tencentâ s affiliates having a big chunk of the rest.

As a private company, Ant does not publish financial data, but analysts covering Alibaba have tried to figure out its revenues and profits. Gregory Zhao, China internet analyst for Barclays in New York, estimates that payments accounted for 55% of Antâ s US$8.9 billion in revenues last year. He expects paymentsâ share of Antâ s total revenues will decline to around 33% within three years as it grows its wealth management and lending businesses. Karen Chan, internet analyst for Jefferies & Co, estimates Ant had operating profits of US$2.1 billion last year. Payments and fintech are a huge opportunity for Alibaba and Tencent, argues JPMorganâ s Cox. â Given that Â­Alibaba and Tencent have a huge existing user base of people transacting on their platforms, it is only natural that they want to expand the usage,â he says.

The way Cox sees it, Ant â may look like a payment business today, but if you fast forward five to 10 years, you might be looking at Ant as Chinaâ s most prominent financial group. The business model has already expanded beyond mere payments to include credit cards, other lending, banking services, wealth management, savings, pensions and insuranceâ .

Ant is reportedly raising US$9 billion from Chinese and global investors, including Singaporeâ s Temasek Holdings, valuing it at over US$150 billion, or almost as much as Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo combined. At that valuation, Alibabaâ s financial arm would be the sixth largest financial institution in the country, just behind Bank of China. Ant is indeed huge; its RMB1.6 trillion ($333.7 billion) Yuâ E Bao money market fund makes up nearly a quarter of Chinaâ s total money market assets.Â 

Bhavtosh Vajpayee, analyst at Sanford Bernstein in Hong Kong, expects Ant to lose money this year and probably next year as it tries to take market share from Tencentâ s financial affiliates. In recent months, regulators in Beijing have cracked down on high interest rate payday loans, peer-to-peer lending, money market funds and cross-border foreign exchange payments. For its part, Ant has put a 24% interest rate ceiling on consumer loans and caps on money market fund investments. Alibaba CEO Jack Ma has promised that Ant will be â socially responsibleâ as it expands its services. EarÂ­lier this year, the Peopleâ s Bank of China decreed that Ant and WeChat Pay should place 42% of their total assets into non-interest-bearing PBOC accounts, from 12% previously. Not being able to put this much-bigger chunk of money to use will cut into Antâ s profitability, says Vajpayee. He notes that Alibaba and Tencent are involved in a fierce subsidy war that could cost between US$2 billion and US$4 billion over the next year. Alibaba is spending billions on merchant subsidies in order to make up for its smaller share in offline payments, he adds.

Cox does not see cut-throat competition and PBOCâ s decision to force them to set a bigger slice aside as a big negative. As Ant and Â­WeBank expand, they are bound to come under the regulatory purvey of the central bank, he says. â They still have a huge user base, they have all the data, they know how to monetise it, they understand how to make online businesses work in what will be, over the next few years, the worldâ s largest economy.â

The JPMorgan portfolio manager argues that the internet giantsâ huge investments in payments as well as growing investments in logistics and offline retail expansion for Â­Alibaba, and gaming and video for Tencent should be seen as moves to build stronger foundations for future growth. He concedes that over the next year or two, their margins are likely to be compressed as they continue to make new investments across a whole range of businesses, but argues that they will remain extremely profitable. â What that means is, in the short run, costs will go up and as such, we might have slightly slower earnings growth,â says Cox. He argues, however, that this is what fast-growing businesses such as Alibaba or Â­Tencent should be doing: â Securing the moat, expanding the network, strengthening the franchise and the entire ecosystem to build a platform for higher long-term growth.â Â 

Whether it is buying offline retail companies or building a large global, fintech business that includes not just payments but also online banking, wealth management and insurance, the investments being made by Alibaba and Tencent are strategically very sound and significant and expected to reap substantial returns over time, says Cox. â Investors are looking beyond one-year or 18-month margin pressures because these investments will lead to much higher margins over the long term and help expand the overall franchise and business of these companies.â

Alibabaâ s Ant and Tencentâ s WeChat Pay and Tenpay have also been expanding their financial services businesses overseas. Tencent has identified Indonesia and Malaysia as markets where it will expand its e-payment services. Ant and Alibaba are shareholders in Paytm, Indiaâ s largest digital payment firm. Last month, Ant paid US$184.5 million for a 45% stake in Telenor Microfinance Bank, a subsidiary of Norwayâ s Â­Telenor that operates a mobile app for financial services in Pakistan. But Ant and Tencent still have no presence in the worldâ s biggest economy, the US. In January, Alibaba was forced to scrap its US$1.2 billion acquisition of US money transfer firm MoneyGram International after the Trump administration objected to the deal.

CDRs or home listings

As they spend to grow their franchise, one key driver over the next year for giants such as Â­Alibaba, Baidu andÂ JD.comÂ that are listed in the US, and Tencent which trades on the Hong Kong bourse, is likely to be mainland listings. Beijing wants these companies to list locally so that Chinese retail investors as well as institutions can partake in their lucrative growth. Alibaba, Tencent and others are reportedly exploring Chinese Depositary Receipts (CDRs), although most analysts do not expect mainland tech listings this year.Â 

One big positive of CDRs is that they will help expand the companiesâ investor base among their core users in mainland China. Detractors say existing shareholdings may be diluted if CDRs involve the issue of new shares. â If it involves the issuance of additional shares, it could be dilutive, but that wonâ t stop Â­Alibaba doing a share buyback and reducing share count,â argues Cox, who notes that the tech behemoths do not need to raise money from the A-shares market. â They have been self-funding for a number of years.â Moreover, the listing of Ant Financial and WeBank and other affiliates as well as subsidiaries over the next few years will keep their coffers overflowing.

After years of heady 40% to 60% annual earnings growth, Tencent and Alibaba are headed towards 20% to 25% growth this year and next, notes Bernsteinâ s Vajpayee. That still makes them among the fastest-growing large tech companies in the world. They are also seen as a â safe havenâ of sorts for investors who are worried about rising protectionism, the spectre of a US-China trade war and punitive tariffs because most of their business is domestic and they are not under the threat of being punished for â stealingâ intellectual property as Washington pushes to rebalance trade flows between US and China. Long after the brouhaha of a trade war is over, Chinaâ s internet giants will still be collecting, harnessing and monetising their customersâ data and boosting their bottom lines.

Assif Shameen is a technology writer based in North America

urn:contentItem:5WN5-67R1-JCF0-4188-00000-00Corporate: Tech: Will Big Tech be broken up or regulated?Â2019-07-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:42ZLexisNexisCorporate: Tech: Will Big Tech be broken up or regulated?Â Assif Shameen

On July 16, top executives from tech behemothsÂ Facebook, Googleâ s ownerÂ Alphabet, Â­Amazon.comÂ andÂ AppleÂ will testify before the US House Committee on the Judiciary. TheÂ congressionalÂ hearing,Â part ofÂ a wide-ranging antitrust probe of the tech players that have a combined market capitalisation of US$3.3 trillion Â­(S$4.49 trillion), will cover their potential threat to competition and innovation as well as whether their continued dominance is harmful to consumers or business rivals.Â 

The moment of truth for global tech Â­giantsÂ is finally here.Â A decadeÂ after the end of the global financial crisis that suddenly catapulted high-growth tech companies with their blitzscaling business models to the forefront as the new drivers of the global economy, US regulators areÂ crackingÂ the whip. Will search giant Google, social media powerhouse Facebook and e-commerce pioneer Amazon be reined in? Will the intense scrutiny of their respective business models eventually lead to antitrust action against one or several of them? Will they be regulated?Â AreÂ Facebook and GoogleÂ in danger of beingÂ broken up?Â 

Silicon Valley behemoths are in the crosshairs of global regulators not because they are among the largest and most profitable businesses on earth, but because they exploit the data we produce as part of the normal course of web browsing, app use and digital consumption as well as making sophisticated inferences about who we are, what we want and what we are likely to do.Â 

HarvardÂ professorÂ Shoshana Zuboff, the author of aÂ new book onÂ the business model of data harvesting,Â The Age of Surveillance Capitalism,Â argues thatÂ Google and Facebook are primarily focused on gathering data about everybody and using it to manipulate choices available to people and getting them to do things or modify behaviour, shaping it towards desired commercial outcomesÂ like generating advertising revenues or e-commerce sales.Â 

Indeed,Â digital platformsÂ such as Google and Facebook are today where the US chemical industry was in the 1950s when they were pouring by-products like mercury and chromium into fresh water, says San Francisco-based veteran venture capitalist Roger Â­McNamee, the author ofÂ Zucked: Waking up to the Facebook Catastrophe. â What we are seeing is the digital equivalent of a toxic oil spill where tech companies, like Facebook and Google, are not bearing the huge cost of the damage they are doing to society,â he says.Â 

Under scrutinyÂ 

Tech giants have been under scrutiny since late 2016 when Facebook was accused of allowing the Russians to manipulate the US presidential elections that put Donald Trump in the White House. Since then, both major parties in America, the Republicans and Democrats, have attacked the tech giants for their political bias, privacy violations, as well as for their business model of extracting too much data without permission and then selling and reselling it for profits.Â 

US regulators, Congressmen and President Trump have stepped up their attacks on data harvesters in recent months. The ascension of William Barr, a known critic of Big Tech, as the US Attorney General in mid-February was the tipping point in the case against the internet giants. â A lot of people wonder how huge behemoths that now exist in Silicon Valley have taken shape under the nose of the antitrust enforcers,â Barr told his Senate confirmation hearings earlier this year.Â Late last month, Trump in a TV interview said that the government â should be Â­suing Google and Facebook, which perhaps we willâ . The president also has a long-running feud with Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, who ownsÂ The Washington Post, a constant critic of his administration.Â 

Antitrust investigations into large, powerful companies are nothing new. In 1984, US regulators broke up giant telco AT&T into small regional â baby bellâ phone companies, which eventually helped Â­usher in a telecommunications revolution. Computer giantÂ IBMÂ survived a Â­13-year antitrust scrutiny between 1969 and 1982.Â Â­Microsoft, which was the dominant player in the personal computer era, barely scraped through after an extensive investigation that began 1998. In April 2000, the Department of Justice (DOJ) ruled that the software giant be broken up, and even though that ruling was later reversed, Microsoft was distracted enough by the scrutiny to miss the internet revolution as well as the switch to mobile communications, clearing the way for the emergence of players such as Amazon, Google and Facebook, and re-emergence of Apple.Â 

In late June, DOJ finally launched an official inquiry into Google. The US Federal Trade Commission is investigating both Facebook and Amazon while DOJ is investigating Apple. FTC has been reportedly working with Facebook for months on a deal that could result in a US$5 billion fine. FTC is likely to take other regulatory actions resulting from the violations of the 2011 consent decree that prohibited Facebook from misleading consumers about their data privacy and security. The social network promised FTC that it would get the explicit consent of users before making changes that overrode their privacy preferences. FTC is also investigating reports that Facebookâ s founder Mark Zuckerberg was aware that his company was in violation of the FTC decree as far back as 2012 and did nothing about it.Â 

To be sure, regulators are moving quickly because the US is in the early stages of a political cycle that will end with fiercely fought presidential elections next November. That aside, there is also a growing awareness that the worldâ s biggest tech firms have issues that are bad for the US, global economy and emerging competitors, as well as consumers around the world.Â 

Very different casesÂ 

Yet each of the cases against the four tech giants could not be more different. Tech industry analysts say the case against Apple, which does not extract personal data without permission or sell data to advertisers, appears trivial. Apple has been criticised for its App Store. Though the company has a mere 17% share of global smartphone market, its App Store accounts for over two-thirds of the total app revenues worldwide.Â 

Music streaming giantÂ SpotifyÂ recently lodged a formal complaint with the EuroÂ­pean Union claiming that Apple uses its App Store to stifle innovation and limit consumer choice in favour of its own Apple Music service. Apple denies the charges and competition lawyers say the problem can been rectified fairly easily by changing the way Apple charges developers who sell their apps on its App Store. Both Apple and its rival Google Play store take a 30% cut from developers or a smaller 15% for in-app purchases. Amazon has some serious structural issues, like its ability to develop competing white-label products at the expense of its brandÂ suppliersÂ and then pushing them at its customers with all the data at its disposal. But Amazon, which despiteÂ its dominance in e-commerceÂ has less than 10% of the US retail market,Â is seen likely to survive any antitrust scrutiny.Â 

For Google and Facebook, the issues go to the heart of their businessÂ model. â Facebookâ s acquisition of Instagram was the greatest regulatory failure of the past decade,â says Taipei-based tech strategist Ben Thompson, who writes the popularÂ StratecheryÂ blog. Regulators doubled down on the mistake by later allowing Facebook to buy WhatsApp. Yet thatÂ does not mean the antitrust scrutiny will lead to severe action like Facebook being forced to divest or hive off Instagram or WhatsApp, a breakup of Google or being put under regulations that basically tie their hands. Still, in Googleâ s case particularly, it is more likely than not that DOJ will force some changes to the business model.Â 

Facebookâ s COO Sheryl Sandberg has been appealing to Americaâ s worst nationalist instincts by arguing that instead of being obsessed with the size and power of the Silicon Valley giants, people should beÂ concerned about the Chinese tech giants that are being nurtured by Beijing and allowed to grow without any obstacles.Â Americaâ s attempts toÂ rein in Facebook and Google are putting its tech leaders at a severe disadvantage in key technologies like artificial intelligence, where it needs to be ahead, against the likes of Chinaâ s home-grown tech champions likeÂ Alibaba Group Holding,Â Tencent HoldingsÂ andÂ Baidu.Â 

Senator Elizabeth Warren,Â a left-leaning Democrat and leading contender for a presidential nomination next year,Â has emerged as the icon of the Big Tech breakup.Â She argues that the tech giants are a clearÂ danger to American democracy, as well as to competition, because there is a massive gathering of data without permission, which is then used in a way that consumers are completely unaware of. â Not only do companies like Facebook and Google extract private data without permission, they pay very little taxes, if any,â Â says Warren, who has been particularly harsh on Amazon and has argued that Apple should be forced to hive off its App Store.

Warren and several other Democratic presidential contenders argue that if Washington breaks up the Big Tech companies, there will be more competition and more innovation, which in turn will only help grow the US economy faster. Silicon Valleyâ s entrepreneurial world has been completely upended as Facebook, Google and Amazon have grown into giant incumbents. Every start-up these days has to have a plan to avoid

competing with these giant incumbents because they would be clobbered if they do,Â the way Facebook started copying everything that

Snapchat did.Â Indeed, the fear of the tech giantsÂ is starting to stifle Â­innovation. The upshot of that is that start-ups these days are trying riskier business models that tend to be capital-Â­intensive, lower-return businesses and venture capitalists are being forced to take bigger risks or walk away.Â 

When American regulators finally do get around to forcing Google, Facebook and others to pay for the cost of the damage they have wreaked over the past decade, they will be a lot less profitable.Â YetÂ that will not makeÂ Facebook or GoogleÂ unattractive businesses â " just more responsible players in the society.

Assif Shameen is a technology writer based in North America
